Abstract

An Operations model will be developed for supporting science projects at Summit Station, in the context of NSF's other activities in Greenland. Input options for logistics, research activities, cost attributes and energy and emission options will be processed in the model. Solutions will be expressed in costs per year, carbon footprints, and operations and logistics strategies. The project will be assisted by a graduate student for two years and upon graduation the knowledge acquired will transfer to the industrial, governmental, and public world. Attempts to recruit a student from a minority or underrepresented group will be undertaken.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Logistics for remote sites such as the operations of NSF in Greenland are challenging to plan due to the inherent dynamic nature of activities. For appropriate planning it is imperative to assess economical and environment impacts of possible expansions. We have developed a logistics network planning model able to assess these metrics for long term planning purposes. The information system uses predictive analytics to model future needs and then by applying optimization it produces an optimal logistics plan. Key performance indicators are displayed by using a business intelligence package. The model has been calibrated based on historical data capturing NSF’s operations in Greenland in support of arctic exploration.

The underlying network design optimization model is challenging to solve by optimization solvers. For this reason we have designed a tailored algorithm relying on decomposition principles. The algorithm iteratively solves problems over much smaller time horizons. The state of the system, which in our case consists of all logistics and operational activities at a given time, and logistics decisions are updated in each iteration by approximating the cost of future decisions. In order to reduce the complexity of the state we have developed a novel approximation capable of solving problems of up to 10 years. The optimization framework does not rely on specifics of our problem and thus it is applicable to a wide range of more general problems.

The information system is able to provide valuable insight to NSF regarding their operations in Greenland. Several long term scenarios have been evaluated spanning from modest annual increases in activities to more drastic changes in the supporting infrastructure.
